;

;;

;

;The picture on the left is Zhou Zuoren, and the picture on the right is "Zhou Zuoren" translated by Nakajima Changfumi Reading Miscellaneous Notes. ;(Pingfanshe 2018/Photo);

;

;;Japanese Translation and Research of Zhou Zuoren;

;

;After coming to Japan to study, although I did not specialize in literature, I liked reading Chido's works when I was in China, and I have always paid attention to the research on him in Japanese academic circles. Interestingly, Japanese Zhidang research is also troubled by political issues. Although there were scholars like Shigeo Matsueda who were loyal to Chido before the war and began to translate and study it, due to political reasons after World War II, there were very few scholars who studied Chido, and translations were also rare. I have seen only one copy, which is "Essays of Zhou Zuoren" translated by Shigeo Matsueda (Toyamabo Encyclopedia Library, 1996), this book is a new compilation of an old book. After World War II, Matsue also co-translated "Lu Xun's Hometown", but his new translation was only this one volume. Hu Shih's treatment was even worse. Only recently has a biography been published. It was a translation of "Hu Shih and the Chinese Renaissance" by American sinologist Grider, which has been published in China for a long time.

;

;Not long after I started graduate school in the mid-1990s, a teacher gave me "The Sorrow of the Oriental People: Zhou Zuoren and Japan" written by Liu Anwei, a PhD student in comparative literature at the University of Tokyo. More than ten years ago, Liu Anwei went a step further and wrote a book called "The Biography of Zhou Zuoren: The Spiritual History of a Literary Man of the Zhini School", which won the prestigious Watsuji Tetsuro Cultural Award. In order to study Zhitang, Liu Anwei even studied ancient Greek. He discussed the ancient Greek classics translated by Zhitang in the book. This made me curious and wanted to read it in full one day. Recently, Liu Anwei also co-published the Japanese translation of "Reminiscences of Zhitang", which provides Japanese readers with good biographical information. In addition to Liu Anwei, some Japanese scholars have also been doing Zhitang research in recent years. For example, Professor Ogawa Toshiyasu, who participated in the editing of "Notes from Zhou Zuoren to Shigeo Matsueda", recently published "Traitor and Hermit: Zhou Zuoren in the 1920s".

;

;In recent years, some of Chido's works have been published in Japanese, such as "Nihon Tan Yi Shu" (Toyo Bunko, 2002) compiled by Chinese literature expert Kiyama Hideo, which includes four "Japanese Glimpses" There are forty-six essays included. As the title of the book indicates, they are all about Japanese culture. The most important one should be the five-volume "Zhou Zuoren's Reading Miscellaneous Notes" compiled by Nakajima Nagabumi, a Chinese literature expert and one of the translators of "Fortress Besieged" (Toyo Bunko, 2018). When I saw an advertisement for Toyo Bunko published in the Asahi Shimbun five years ago, the author was shocked because I had the impression that Toyo Bunko had never published five books by the same person. I really admire the courage of this publishing house. After all, it is an old publishing house that has published Japan's best encyclopedia and "Collected Works of Lin Dafu" and other good books. By chance, I recently borrowed this set of books and read several translations and explanations carefully. I found that it is indeed a good translation that has put a lot of effort into it. It is worth introducing it to domestic readers and seeing how Japanese scholars read it. Zhitang's.

;

;;

;

;Zhou Zuoren and his friends are in Kuyu Zhai. ;(Information picture/picture);

;

;;The best Japanese version of Chido's works;

;

;We know that Zhitang read countless books throughout his life, and many of the articles he wrote were related to books. In the words of his student Zhang Zhongxing, Zhitang ranks among the best among the older generation in terms of the amount of reading and the variety of reading. Therefore, Professor Nakajima compiled and selected Zhidou's articles from the perspective of reading. It was a very insightful decision to name this set of books "Zhou Zuoren's Reading Miscellaneous Notes". It can be said that it captured the main thread of Zhidou's lifelong pursuit of knowledge. The text used as the translation base was "Zhitang Shuhua" which I had read back then. However, he used a newer version, a two-volume version published by Renmin University of China Press in 2004. The "Chitō Preface and Postscripts" that was published at about the same time as "Chitō Shuhua" was basically not included in the collection, because in Professor Nakajima's opinion, Chitō wrote the preface and postscript to the books he had personally seen, and as a translator, he had to verify them one by one. It's not easy, I have to give up. In order to fully reflect the complete picture of Chitou's works, Professor Nakajima said that he also referred to "Zhou Zuoren's Collected Works", "Zhou Zuoren's Humanities Collection", "Zhou Zuoren's Complete Prose Collection" and "Zhou Zuoren's Complete Translations", which means that it is a fact Above are five volumes selected from all the works. The translator's seriousness in choosing the original text for translation is truly admirable.

;

;After determining the general direction, how to arrange the specific volumes is also a very difficult matter. After all, the articles written by Zhitang cover a wide range of knowledge and the number of articles is amazing. In his own words, his knowledge is "horizontal" and "miscellaneous knowledge". Therefore, Nakajima simply placed the autobiographical article "My Miscellaneous Studies" at the beginning of the first volume. This is the best introduction, allowing Japanese readers who are not familiar with Chido to have an overview of this foreign literati and thinker. learn. After all, compared to his brother, his popularity in Japan is vastly different. Lu Xun's articles have even been included in Japanese middle school Chinese textbooks. The first volume is after "My Miscellaneous Studies", and the translator also divided it into sub-categories such as reading theory, banned books, and book records, and included related articles.

;

;;

;

;Two scholars who had a greater influence on Zhou Zuoren are Ailisi on the left and Kunio Yanagida on the right. ;(Information picture/picture);

;

;The second volume is mainly articles related to folk customs. Zhitang's concern for folk customs lasted throughout his life, and he was a very prominent figure in the history of modern Chinese culture. In Nakajima’s words, in terms of mythology and folklore, Chido can be regarded as the founder of modern Chinese related knowledge. He is not only familiar with the knowledge of the British classical master Ms. Jane Harrison, but also highly respects modern Japanese folklore. Kunio Yanagida, the founder of the school. The third volume includes articles related to women and sexuality. Nakajima said that Chido’s motivation for being very concerned about women and sexual issues is still unclear even now, but at least he was ideologically influenced by the British scholar Ellis. Including relevant articles in the third volume is also a very discerning choice. After all, this is an extremely important part of Zhitang's lifelong study and thinking. Zhitang said that the one who had the greatest influence on him was Elisabeth. According to Zhang Zhongxing, Zhitang has read more than three million words of Elis's works, including the seven-volume "Research on Sexual Psychology", which shows the great influence.

;

;In fact, there is no unified standard for the classification of this set of Japanese translations of Chido's reading miscellanies. Nakajima said that starting from the middle of the third volume, the classification changed from title to classification. He said that it was actually inspired by "I The influence of "Miscellaneous Studies" is basically similar to the classification of Zhitang Shuxue. The fourth volume is composed of Zhitang's articles discussing old and new Chinese literature. The fifth volume contains many articles about notes, as well as old novels. Zhitang loved to read notes throughout his life. We can know from his collection that he read a large number of notes from past dynasties. Needless to say, his writing style was also affected. Many of his own articles are good notes.

;

;After carefully reading Professor Nakajima’s selection and classification, the author feels that the articles he selected have included Chido’s lifelong academic thoughts. The author has also read some translations, and the quality is very good. It should be said that these five volumes of translations have provided Japanese readers with trustworthy texts.

;

;;

;

;Professor Liu Anwei from the Institute of Liberal Arts Education, Tokyo Institute of Technology, Japan, and his representative work "The Biography of Zhou Zuoren". ;(Tokyo Institute of Technology website/picture);

;

;;An unmissable explanation;

;

;I I originally thought that I had been reading Chitou's works for many years, and I didn't care if I didn't read the explanations attached to each book. However, after reading a few pages, I realized that I was completely wrong. When I patiently read the five-volume commentary, I was first moved by the translator's efforts, because each commentary was very long, some nearly thirty pages, and the shortest nearly ten pages. In order to make it easier for Japanese readers to read, in addition to introducing a lot of background materials, the most interesting part is the part where Professor Nakajima talks about his views on Chido. There are not only praises, but also sharp criticisms, and some from the Japanese perspective. Some of his profound insights have never been discovered before. Here are some selected ones to introduce.

;

;For example, when talking about Zhitang's concern for mythology and folklore, Nakajima pointed out that Zhitang's related work was all carried out in his study, and he only collected two hundred works in Shaoxing in 1913. A nursery rhyme. Nakajima said that this was very different from Yanagida Kunio, whom Chitou admired. Yanagida Kunio traveled all over Japan to collect folklore materials and established a set of learning rules for Japanese folklore. Nakajima also pointed out that as both study-type scholars, Chitou is different from Fraser, the author of "The Golden Bough", because he does not engage in classification work or analyze data, which means that he does not do systematic work. This point is indeed to the point. Maybe it has something to do with Zhitang's way of doing academics. After all, he has never felt the need or pressure to write a paper, and has always written in the form of essays. Nakajima's criticism also made the author have some associations.

;

;I have heard a saying before that Zhou Zuoren is known as the best Japanese scholar in China, but he is not a real scholar who studies Japan. At first glance, I was shocked because I instinctively refuted it. Is there any Chinese scholar who knows more about Japanese culture than Chitou? But thinking about it calmly, Chido did not conduct research on Japanese culture by writing a paper. He mainly wrote his observations and analysis of Japanese culture in the form of essays. The same goes for his work on folklore and mythology. Nakajima pointed out that the same characteristics are also reflected in Chido’s focus on and research on women and sexual psychology. He said that Zhitang's method is based on conscious individuals and is not combined with mass movements, so in practice the effect is zero. In other words, Zhitang wanted to enlighten people through articles, but the result was like waiting for the Yellow River to clear up.

;

;;

;

;Zhou Zuoren in his later years. ;(Information picture/picture);

;

;There is a saying that the best way to read is to translate. As a translator, Nakajima can be said to have thoroughly read Chido's major works, and as a result of repeated scrutiny, he has an understanding of Chido's texts that ordinary readers do not have. For example, one of the issues pointed out by Nakajima, which I have not paid much attention to before, is the understanding of Yanagida Kunio.

;

;Chido has an article about Yanagida Kunio's masterpiece "Tono Monogatari", and the title of the article is "Tono Monogatari". Nakajima said that when Chitō read Yanagita’s book, he read it in the same way as when he read Hao Yixing and Yu Zhengxie, that is, based on the criteria of thoroughness of thought and readability of the article, but for the most important thing Yanagida’s article wanted to convey, It's folklore, but I don't pay too much attention to it, that is to say, I don't look at it from a cultural perspective. In other words, Chido admits that Yanagita's book has both the beauty of writing and the value of folklore, but he seems unable to see what he has excavated from Yanagita's folklore and what he has elaborated on it. Such criticism reminds me of Chido’s own words. He said he just likes to read miscellaneous books and learn more about things. I am neither a scholar nor a scholar, I am just doing odd jobs. Comparing the two sides, it may be easier to understand. Nakajima also said that there is no harm in appreciating Yanagita's article as a good text, but if the folklore meaning is not read, misunderstandings are likely to occur.

;

;When Sino-Japanese relations were deteriorating, Chitou expressed his confusion about his Japanese research. For example, in "Japanese Insights No. 4" written in June 1937, he said that he admired the beautiful Japan cannot be linked to Japan, which invaded China in reality. Chitou confessed that he could not understand Japan like that, and said that he usually felt that the Japanese nation was very different from China, and that was religious beliefs. To borrow Yanagita Kunio's statement, the Japanese worship rituals often show a state of "harmony between gods and gods". Chido said that Japan's upper-class intellectual circles have absorbed Chinese Confucianism and Indian Buddhism, and in modern times have added Western philosophy and science. However, the fundamental belief of the nation seems to be Shintoism from Southeast Asia, which has always dominated the thoughts and feelings of the people. . Nakajima also talked about this part. He said that although Chitou said that he did not understand, in fact, he had basically pointed out the truth of the matter here, because Chitou said that if he could understand the psychology of the strong man who carries the shrine, he would Able to understand Japan's actions against China. Nakajima said that here Chido finally made full use of Yanagita's folklore results not from a literary perspective but from a folklore perspective. The analysis of Japan's invasion of China was not just from the perspective of upper-class politicians, soldiers and intellectuals, but from the perspective of upper-class politicians, soldiers and intellectuals. Turn your attention to the people. Yanagita's purpose in studying folklore is to unearth those thinking and psychological mechanisms that cannot be simply rationalized. They are accumulated in the unconsciousness of the group and restrict the behavior of the people. Nakajima said that Chido had studied Yanagita for so many years, and now he really understood what Yanagita was talking about. Nakajima's analysis is indeed very sharp, because this is an issue that is difficult for us Chinese readers to detect.

;

;;

;

;Japanese scholar Yoshikawa Kojiro. ;(Information picture/picture);

;

;Writing this, I remembered the words of another great scholar, Kojiro Yoshikawa, recalling his meeting with Chitō. . At the beginning of the article "The Significance and Methods of Foreign Studies", Yoshikawa said that he met Chido in Beijing shortly after the outbreak of the Sino-Japanese War. He said Chitou told him that his Japanese studies paid too much attention to the Chinese-influenced aspects of Japanese culture and did not pay enough attention to Japanese religion. These were fatal flaws. Yoshikawa said he answered bluntly that it was indeed the case. In fact, he spoke highly of Chido's Japanese studies, because in his opinion, most Chinese people at that time did not recognize the uniqueness of Japanese culture, but Chido loved Japan deeply and advocated that Japan had its own culture. In this regard, Yoshikawa believed that Japan People and the Japanese government should express their gratitude. However, in his view, Zhou Zuoren’s Japanese research was actually too biased towards the Heian period, towards the late Edo and Meiji periods of a certain school of literati (should refer to the Shirakaba school), and although these can be said to represent Japanese literature era, but it cannot represent the era of Takeshi in Japan. Even if we cannot say that these are very Chinese parts of Japanese culture, they are indeed an era that Chinese intellectuals can easily understand. Yoshikawa went on to say that Japan still has eras of representative martial arts, such as the Kamakura shogunate, and the religions of Nichiren and Shinran that emerged in the Kamakura period play an important role in Japanese history. These Japanese people are very aware. However, it has been almost completely ignored in Chido's Japanese studies. The reason for this is that Yoshikawa believes that the Chinese people attach great importance to literature. Japan's national character of attaching importance to martial arts is inconsistent with Chinese tradition. Yoshikawa said there is another reason, and that is the lack of religion in Chinese culture. Yoshikawa believed that Confucianism was strongly opposed to the idea of ​​finding an ideal world after death, in a super-sensory place separated from the human world. Although this tendency was weakened by the entry of Buddhism, it soon rebounded and was completely finalized by the time of Confucianism in the Song Dynasty. Japan is the opposite of China, and it is here that Japan has its most special place. In Yoshikawa's view, because Japan was the opposite of China in terms of religion, even the erudite Chido was not interested in it, so his research on Japan was biased, which also led to his inability to understand Japan's military operations. Yoshikawa even said that Japan’s China studies should take Chido as a lesson and reflect on whether they have made the same mistakes.

;

;;

;

;Jiang Baili. ;(data map/picture);

;

;Yoshikawa's analysis and criticism of Chido's Japanese studies can be seen together with Nakajima's More complete. The author believes that Jiang Baili, a contemporary of Chitang, has the most accurate understanding of the martial side of Japanese culture. After all, Jiang Baili had a military background, attended a Japanese military academy, and had some friends in the Japanese military circles. He was very familiar with Japan. The grasp of characteristics is most accurate among Chinese Nippon Tongli, and some views even predicted the outcome of the war. We will understand after reading his "Japanese—A Study of a Foreigner". Although Chido is proficient in Japanese culture and has many friends in the literary and art circles in Japan, his Japanese studies do have problems with the study style. His misjudgment of the situation may also have something to do with this.

;

;When talking about Zhitang's unique literary outlook, of course he will mention his high evaluation of short essays in the late Ming Dynasty. Nakajima's explanatory essays not only set off a craze in China, but also influenced Chinese literature researchers in Japan across the sea. The author is very ignorant and this is the first time I have heard of this. Nakajima said that as far as he knew, at least two famous scholars were affected. One was Iriya Yoshitaka, and the other was Ogawa Tamaki, who was the first to introduce Qian Zhongshu's "Selected Annotations to Song Poems" in Japan. Yoshitaka Iriya has researched Ming Dynasty literature and is also known for his research on Zen Buddhism. According to Nakajima, Ogawa Tamaki did not directly study the late Ming Dynasty sketch essays, but he always loved reading Chitou's articles. He followed the lead and collected most of the books mentioned in Chitou's articles, and now they are all collected in the Ogawa Bunko. Nakajima said that he benefited a lot from Ogawa Bunko when translating. When I read this, I thought it was a coincidence, because I have a set of "Collected Works of Ogawa Tamaki" published by Chikuma Shobo, which is very close to Chido's works.

;

;;

;

;Hello Takeuchi. ;(Information picture/picture);

;

;;Enlightenment and falling into the water;

;

;In summary Zhitang When it comes to the characteristics of a lifetime's work, Nakajima said it can be summed up in four words: "physical human feelings." For Zhitang, this "physical favor" is not only the standard of value for judging literary works, but also the standard for judging all things. This point of view is completely consistent with Zhang Zhongxing's point of view in the article "Re-Talk about Kuyu Zhai". Nakajima also said that to sum it up in more popular terms is "reasonable thinking and humane feelings", which is the essence of the Enlightenment spirit that Chido absorbed from his own civilization and foreign ideas. At the same time, this is also the most important prescription Zhitang wants to use to solve China's fundamental problems. Nakajima said that precisely because of this, his contribution should not be erased because of political missteps. Interestingly, Nakajima changed his tone at this time and talked about the difficulties encountered by this enlightenment spirit in the 21st century. He said that he originally thought that this "physical human relationship" that integrated the essence of Eastern and Western thought would still be effective in another hundred years. However, after entering the 21st century, he found that almost all his ideals were shattered, so he began to doubt whether this enlightenment spirit also had limitations. . The reason for this suspicion is that the Japanese have already led a life of abundant food and clothing, and education is universal. Almost everyone can enter high school, and nearly 60% of them can enter university. Regardless of quality, this is an astonishing number. It stands to reason that this number is very close to the ideals held by people with lofty ideals in modern times, but irresponsibility is prevalent in society where no one is responsible (this is reminiscent of the "irresponsibility system" said by the famous political thinker Maruyama Masao) ), the democratic system seems to have turned into populism, which can be said to have the tendency of obscurantism. In this case, how to promote "physical favors"? If that were the case, wouldn’t all the efforts of the enlightenment sages back then be in vain? This question is too big, and I am not capable of answering it. However, Nakajima is very keenly aware of the serious problems that modern enlightenment may bring. Adorno and Horkheimer, who wrote "Dialectics of Enlightenment", have long warned about this. , Nakajima is just repeating an old story. However, he was able to discuss the enlightenment concept of "physical human relations" together with the enlightenment trends in modern times, which shows his broad vision, because after all, our enlightenment is closely related to the West.

;

;It is impossible to write about Zhitang without mentioning his falling into the water. As mentioned earlier, Professor Nakajima believes that he cannot be completely dismissed because of this incident. This is consistent with the spirit of Mr. Zhong Shuhe’s saying that people should return to their own people and the article should return to the article. But how do you view this matter from a Japanese perspective? I remember that many years ago when I was reading Takeuchi Yoshi's "Inside China", I saw him mention Chitou, and he said that we Japanese were sorry for him. Professor Nakajima said something similar in the explanation, but more specific, which moved me as a Chinese reader very much. He said that it was our grandfathers and fathers’ generation who carried Chitou out like a scarecrow in a wind and rain festival, made him sit on the shrine, and then threw it to the roadside outside the village. In other words, the great-grandfathers or great-grandfathers’ parents of those working in society today. Their names cannot be remembered, but they are all Japanese. We should not forget this.

;

;However, no matter what the external reasons are, it is Chitou’s own judgment after all, and the blame cannot be placed on others. However, the opinions of Takeuchi Yoshi and Nakajima Nagafumi, two Japanese scholars who have studied Chinese culture all their lives, If there is any Zhitang who knows this, he will definitely be very moved by these words.

;

;;Something about the translator of Zhitang;

;

;After reading Professor Nakajima’s last explanation, I felt particularly respectful. He said that this translation work was originally proposed by the editor of Pingfanshe in 2005, and it took a total of 13 years. It was really a long and protracted battle. Considering his physical strength and age, it was not easy to last until the end.

;

;When talking about Japanese Chido translators, he highlighted Shigeo Matsueda and Hideo Kiyama and paid tribute to them. In his later years, when sorting out Chitou's letters, Matsueda Shigeo once said, "Half of his life, he fell in love with the Dream of Red Mansions, but his whole life, he fell in love with Zhou Zuoren." The former refers to his translation of "A Dream of Red Mansions", and the latter, of course, refers to the correspondence between him and Chitou from their student days to Chitou's later years. Communicated. It is said that Matsueda Shigeo once planned to translate all Chido's works, but he was unable to realize this long-cherished wish. In 1973, his student Hideo Kiyama collected Chido's articles on Japanese culture and compiled them into the book "Japanese Culture", which was the predecessor of "Nihon Tan Yoshiro" included in Toyo Bunko. Mushan also interviewed insiders and wrote a book about Zhitang's fall into the water, "The whole story of Zhou Zuoren's cooperation with Japan - Supplementary Notes and Sequels to "The Story of Kuzhu'an in Beijing"", which is unavoidable for all readers who are interested in that period of history. past works. He also assisted his octogenarian teacher in compiling and publishing the "Essays of Zhou Zuoren" mentioned earlier, which included thirty-nine famous articles written by Zhitang up to the 1930s. In addition to translation, Mr. Matsue, who rarely writes, wrote an article "Mr. Zhou Zuoren". Although it was written in 1941, it is one of the best articles about Zhitang that the author has seen.

;

;After reading Zhitang’s articles for so many years, I finally have the opportunity to write about Zhitang. It is still the old saying of Mr. Zhong Shuhe, people will return to their people, and the article will return to the article. Zhitang's political mistakes are indeed regrettable and make the readers who admire him feel worthless for him, because Hu Shi said that a wise man should understand lightly. and serious, but he made a judgment that shocked the people of the country. But his works have their own value of being handed down from generation to generation. After all, Zhitang left a valuable asset to the history of Chinese culture and thought, and some of his ideas still retain their brilliance. It is said that after Hu Shi returned to Taiwan in the 1950s, he asked people to collect Zhitang's works everywhere. He said that the works of this old friend were still worth reading since the May Fourth Movement. Although it is not without exaggeration, it also tells the undeniable truth. The work of Japanese scholars introduced in this article can also provide us with some new ideas for understanding Zhitang.

;;Since 2021, Ruby Lin has As a producer, he rode the wave of the revival of Taiwanese dramas and launched many popular dramas: the female entrepreneurship drama "The Story of Their Entrepreneurship", the suspense-style female group drama "The First Light of the Night", and the The large-scale crime suspense drama "Copycat", and she achieved a reputation reversal with these popular dramas.

;

;In the Douban short review section of the latest Taiwanese drama "In This Lifetime", everyone also gave unanimous praise - "I am willing to pay Ruby Lin to make 100 films a year." "Ruby Ruby's production is a guarantee of quality. ”

;

;;While affirming the quality of the series, she also affirmed her vision as a producer. ;

;

;;

;

;;

;

;;The Taiwanese drama "Once Upon a Time" scored a high score of 8.8 after its premiere. It is one of the most popular Chinese dramas in recent times.

;

;;;

;;It brings together the backbone of the Taiwanese film and television industry: director Xu Zhaoren, who has directed dramas such as "Love Knot Chitose's First Love", "Skyscraper" and "Love Is Delicious"; screenwriter Du Zhengzhe is Ruby Lin's The gold medal partners have worked together in "16 Summers" and "The Lights Are Coming" and won the Golden Bell Award; in terms of actors, there are young actors like Wu Kangren, Zheng Yuanchang, and Zhang Rongrong, as well as veteran actors like Xixiang and Yang Guimei. ;

;

;;For countless audiences who have watched the film, the story of "In This Life Time" is no stranger. It is similar to the movie "A Man Called Ove Decides to Die" 》Similarly, it also relies on the idea of ​​​​"suicide". Introduced from the perspective of the male protagonist, it peels away the ordinary daily life, pays attention to the close connection between people, and then draws the conclusion that this connection is both a dilemma and a harbor.

;

;;;

;;The 41-year-old male protagonist Gao Jiayue (played by Wu Kangren) is a "loser" in the secular sense. When he was young, he took NT$1 million given by his mother to open a restaurant in a foreign country. However, the business failed and the restaurant was on the verge of bankruptcy. At the same time, his girlfriend of 12 years also openly cheated on her and became pregnant with someone else's child. A third party came not only to destroy the store, but also to "rob" his life.

;

;Gao Jiayue parted ways with his girlfriend, but he still couldn’t figure out what his problem was. His girlfriend mocked him: “You will never understand what I’m talking about in this life, but you can consider reincarnation, maybe in the next life. You will understand."

;

;;

;

;;These words from his girlfriend stimulated Gao Jiayue's thoughts of committing suicide. He attempted suicide several times without success. Then he decided to dive into the depths of the sea, unplug his oxygen tank, throw away his equipment, and wait for death. ;

;

;;But when he was floating alone on the sea, he suddenly thought of his family. This gave him the idea of ​​saying goodbye. ;So, after being away from home for more than ten years, he returned home again and reconnected with his family and the world as an "uninvited guest". ;;

;

;;

;

;;The title of the drama "In My Lifetime" is actually the name of Gao Jiayue's suicide note: it was originally named "Suicide Note", but he crossed it out; it was changed to "The Long Farewell" Finally, he crossed it out again; he was afraid that the "suicide note" was too heavy and the "farewell" was too sad. After repeated evaluation;;, he finally wrote this line - "It is not bad to grow up to this size in my lifetime." Now.";

;

;;

;It's just that in "The Story of a Common Girl", the plight of middle-aged women is directly addressed. The heroine has a clear understanding of her own life dilemma and will speak out without any scruples. Cry loudly. The portrayal of the male protagonist's situation in "In This Lifetime" is much more restrained, which is more in line with the impression of "a man will not shed tears easily". ;

;

;;

;

;;Gao Jiayue is the eldest son of the family. When he returned home, he found that everyone in the family was not living as he wished and was going through their own tribulations in life. ;

;

;;My parents have a cold relationship and have been sleeping in separate rooms for many years. My father was cheating on the little nurse in the hospital, and my mother knew it, but for the sake of face, she could only tolerate it. ;

;

;;Because he is an adopted son, the second brother Gao Jiayang consciously assumes more support obligations, but he is very tired because of the elders and children. At the same time, he also tries to get in touch with his biological children. parents. ;

;

;;

;

;;The third brother Gao Jiakai does not have a formal job, so he works in his parents' breakfast shop. He obviously has a girlfriend, but he is secretive and dare not let his family know. ;

;

;;My nephew Gao Chengyou is in his adolescence. He is worried about online dating and causing trouble on campus. ;

;

;;

;

;;The arrival of Gao Jiayue is like a fuse, causing family conflicts to break out. He tried hard to please his family, but he always accidentally made the atmosphere at home extremely awkward. ;

;

;;But even so, the family's concern still flowed silently into Gao Jiayue's heart. He came home drunk without saying hello. After going crazy, he passed out on the sofa. His father stayed with him all night. ;

;

;;

;

;;There was already a rift between the parents, but in order to make room for Gao Jiayue, they still lived together again. ;

;

;;The second brother was lukewarm towards Gao Jiayue. Seeing him doing nothing after returning home, he couldn't help but beat him: "You are still chewing on the old at this age, don't you think Is your life a failure?" However, in order to make his eldest brother sleep more comfortably, he took the initiative to buy a mattress for his eldest brother. ;

;

;;Even the nephew Gao Chengyou cares about Gao Jiayue in his own way. Gao Chengyou accidentally saw Gao Jiayue's suicide note, but instead of revealing his uncle's secret, he introduced his "online girlfriend" to his uncle, hoping to satisfy Gao Jiayue's wish to "have a good relationship." ;

;

;;

;

;;As a family drama about the flow of life;, the biggest feature of "Lifetime" is that it firmly grasps the word "life" and captures the warmth in the short stories of the parents. Feeling the sorrow and joy of ordinary people while stumbling. As netizens said, "This is not a drama, this is a documentary."

;

;My nephew Gao Chengyou's friend encountered ;school violence at school and committed suicide by jumping off a building. As a middle school student, Gao Chengyou was more helpless. His most "deviant" move was that with the help of Gao Jiayue, he occupied the school radio room and sang in memory of his friends. ;

;

;;

;

;;In terms of shooting techniques;, the play uses a large number of long shots to express family relationships in space, of which two are the most impressive.

;

;One scene is the night Gao Jiayue arrived home and came in drunk. The camera followed him and brought out the relationships and personalities of the Gao family through the process of him embracing his family.

;

;In another place, the next night the three brothers of the Gao family celebrated their father's birthday. In a slightly cramped space, Gao's mother was comforting Gao Chengyou who had been scolded, while the second brother was blaming;Gao Jiayue, weird He led his son to fool around on campus, while Gao Jiayue retorted absentmindedly and poured vinegar into the pot by mistake for soy sauce...;

;

;;For more than twenty seconds The picture condenses the family's exciting evening stories and family ties, making people feel that this is a real Fujian family. ;

;

;;

;

;; "In This Lifetime" has a total of 12 episodes. The frequency of weekly updates and the soothing plot may prevent it from becoming a big hit. But for lovers of slice-of-life dramas, it's palatable enough. ;

;

;;This kind of plain and freehand flow of life allows people to relieve their impetuous minds, accept the unsatisfactory life, and feel its warm and healing moments. ;

;Recently I saw a saying, "Grow slower and die faster." It may sound a bit confusing at first, but in fact it explains the truth of life very clearly.

;

;To put it simply, a person should try his best to age slowly, keep his mind young, live a quality and glorious life, and once he faces death and there is no way to recover, he should have a good time. , be optimistic about life, and don’t go against objective laws and make meaningless “struggles”.

;

;A friend talked about an incident. An old man had entered the last moments of his life, and a relative with whom he had a very good relationship was out of town. The old man’s children considered letting them see each other for the last time, so they prepared to use the ultimate method to Medical means extend the life of the old man and let him "wait" for his arrival. He considered and refused again and again, on the grounds that it would add unnecessary pain to the old man before he died. Even if it "makes sense" to him, it's not humane.

;

;Everyone is afraid of the word "old". Many people are desperately looking for beauty treatments, no matter how much money they spend, they are not afraid of getting old. There are also many people who are obviously old, but they are taboo about being called "aunt" or "uncle". But physical aging is an objective law that no one can resist. "Are you young? It doesn't matter, you will be old in two years." Zhang Ailing's famous saying fully expresses the impact of the law of aging on the illusion of "eternal youth".

;

;"Old" can be divided into two situations. One is that the body ages and the body functions become weaker. The original straight back has collapsed, the original beautiful features have turned into a "mess", the original speedy steps have turned into slowly moving steps with a cane... The second is psychological or spiritual aging. Some people have a good mentality and appear young, even if they are seventy or eighty years old, they are not old. Some people age faster than their peers under heavy pressure. The so-called "a 30-year-old has a 60-year-old heart" and "premature aging" all have this meaning. The latter type of people is actually more common. Their hallmark is that they want to work hard on the "Hot Wheels" every day, and they also frown and sigh all day long, accompanied by white hair and wrinkled faces.

;

;For those who are not involved in childbirth and are pampered, it is relatively easy to achieve the goal of aging slower. Even at different stages of a person, there are big differences. For example, the "Sha Wujing" who was leisurely swimming in the Liusha River back then must be more beautiful than the Sha Wujing who was walking on the road to seek Buddhist scriptures, eating and sleeping in the open and carrying everyone's luggage on his shoulders. Appear youthful.

;

;Most people cannot have freedom of wealth, nor can they rely on others to support themselves without working. This will inevitably lead to people plotting for rice and trying their best to get tomorrow’s steamed buns. Because in reality, it is not easy to make a living, and there are all kinds of internal and external frictions all the time, so there are nine out of ten people who are exhausted both mentally and physically.

;

;What to do? As ordinary people, since we cannot change our situation, the only thing we can do is to take it lightly.

;

;I once had a neighbor who was in his nineties and could ride a bicycle very fast. Why? In fact, he was not strong when he was young. Instead, he had problems here and there, but he just had a good mentality. Whether you encounter a small trouble or encounter a hurdle that others may think is almost insurmountable, you should be able to deal with it calmly, think less, and worry less. Such people should live longer. "Be heartless and live a long life" may not sound good, but the words are rough and rational, and the mentality of "if you can afford it, let it go" is worth learning.

;

;A person should work hard when working, and should also "try hard" to rest when resting. That is, he should neither be distracted when he should be working, always thinking about lying down, nor should he be lying down when he should be working. I always think about work when I am resting, and as a result, my work is not good and my rest is not good either.

;

;You can enter the world and you can emerge from it. This is the highest state of life. It seems difficult to achieve, but it is not. How to work and how to rest is a science. As an individual, you must learn to adjust, relax the tight strings at the right time, balance work with rest, and laugh at gains and losses. This is a skill that can be mastered. If you can't do it the first time, do it again.

;

;People are afraid of old age and even talk about death.

;

;Speaking of "die faster", this does not conform to the philosophy of many Chinese people. In contrast, it is greed for life and fear of death. Even if you die a moment later, it seems to be good. This is instinctive and understandable.

;

;In order to die slowly, many people (mainly family members of the deceased) do whatever they can to survive. As long as they can breathe one more breath in the human world, they are willing to suffer all kinds of hardships. This mentality has far-reaching influence. Most of the savings of many people's lives are not spent while enjoying life and raising children, but are thrown into the water in a "surprise attack" one or two months before death. Death is already an irreversible outcome. No matter how much money is spent, it is in vain. At most, it can delay the death a little. In the end, one person will lose both his life and property, and even his children and grandchildren will be burdened with heavy debts. It is really not worth it.

;

;In the face of disease, some people are even "scared to death". As soon as they heard that they had an incurable disease, they would fall into a state of panic and disorder, causing physical and mental harm and exacerbating physical diseases.

;

;The most difficult thing in life is to remain transparent on the subject of death. If a slower death equals long-term torture—including torture for children—then the meaning of life will also change.

;

;My father told me that there was an old lady in the family who lived alone and lived to a ripe old age. She had done "white things" during her lifetime, and she became a favorite story in the village. If a person has seen through life and death, and the true meaning of "disappearance", what is there to be afraid of, and why must he do it even though he knows it cannot be done?

;

;To let go of life calmly is a kind of great love. It’s not about going against the trend and forcibly delaying death, it’s about cherishing life. Knowing the deadline, waving your hands and going away, isn’t it a kind of optimism towards life?

;

;Of course, there is no need to doubt the significance of saving lives and healing the wounded. Reducing illness and pain in life is a legitimate pursuit. But what we need to take warning from is gambling-like “fighting” in order to die slowly.

;

;There are reports that after someone learned that he had terminal cancer, he specifically told his closest relatives not to needless treatment, let alone to "intubate" himself when he was dying, so as not to spend more money. . Having such an open heart is a rational choice after insight. Of course, financial hardship is also one of the reasons, but in general, it is still based on optimism about life and great love for family.

;

;To grow old slowly and die quickly is my creed and pursuit.

;
